definitions: cause something to happen suddenly or too soon without proper consideration
fall as rain, snow, sleet, or hail from clouds in the sky
cause a substance to separate from a solution and form a solid deposit
examples: The scandal precipitated the minister's resignation from office
His careless remarks precipitated a major diplomatic crisis
Heavy snow will precipitate across the northern regions tonight
Moisture precipitates when warm air meets cold surfaces
Adding acid will precipitate the proteins from the solution
The chemical reaction precipitated crystals at the bottom

definitions: prevent something from happening or someone from doing something by taking action in advance
make something impossible or prevent it from being considered as an option
examples: The contract precludes any changes without mutual consent
Bad weather precluded the possibility of outdoor activities
His criminal record precludes him from government employment
The high cost precludes most people from buying it

definitions: establish something as a necessary condition that must be met beforehand
prepare or influence someone or something in advance for a particular purpose
examples: The agreement preconditions funding on meeting specific targets
They preconditioned their support on policy changes being made
The therapist preconditioned patients before starting the main treatment
Years of training had preconditioned him for this challenge

definitions: exist or occur at a date before something else in time
mark a document or check with a date that is earlier than the actual date
examples: These ruins predate the Roman occupation by several centuries
His illness predates his retirement from professional sports
She predated the check to avoid a late payment penalty
The letter was deliberately predated to establish priority

definitions: base or establish something on a particular principle, condition, or fact
assert or affirm something about the subject of a proposition in logic
state or assert something as an attribute or quality of something
examples: The theory predicates its conclusions on questionable assumptions
Success is predicated on hard work and dedication
The philosopher predicates existence of the divine being
Logic predicates certain truths about mathematical relationships
The report predicates serious problems with the current system
She predicated her decision on thorough market research

definitions: say or estimate that something will happen in the future based on knowledge or experience
state or declare something before it actually happens or is known
examples: Scientists predict global temperatures will rise significantly
The model accurately predicted the election results
No one could have predicted such dramatic changes
She predicted that the company would face challenges

definitions: make someone likely to be affected by a particular condition or to behave in a particular way
influence someone or something in advance to react or think in a particular way
examples: Genetic factors predispose some people to heart disease
His childhood experiences predisposed him to anxiety
The media coverage predisposed voters against the candidate
Early training predisposes children to enjoy reading

definitions: be the largest in number or the most important element in something
have or exert control or power over others in a particular area
examples: Oak trees predominate in this ancient forest ecosystem
Traditional values still predominate in rural communities
Large corporations predominate in the technology sector
Her influence predominates in all committee decisions

definitions: take action in order to prevent something from happening or to seize an opportunity before others
replace a scheduled television or radio program with something considered more important
examples: The company preempted competitors by launching their product early
Military forces preempted the enemy attack with defensive measures
Breaking news preempted the regular evening programming
The presidential address will preempt all scheduled shows

definitions: introduce something spoken or written with preliminary remarks or explanatory notes
provide an introduction or preliminary explanation to a book, speech, or other work
examples: He prefaced his criticism with several positive comments
The speaker prefaced her remarks with a personal anecdote
The author prefaced the novel with historical background information
She prefaced each chapter with relevant quotations

definitions: like one thing or person better than another or value it more highly
promote or advance someone to a higher position or give them special treatment
examples: Most customers prefer online shopping to visiting stores
She prefers coffee over tea in the morning
The company preferred internal candidates for senior positions
He was preferred over more experienced applicants

definitions: attach a word element to the beginning of a word to modify its meaning
add something to the beginning of something else as an introduction or modification
examples: You can prefix 'un' to many adjectives to create opposites
The code prefixes all variables with their data type
She prefixed her presentation with a brief personal story
They prefixed each file name with the date

definitions: cause someone to have an unfair or unreasonable opinion about something or someone
harm or damage the success, credibility, or effectiveness of something
examples: Media coverage might prejudice the jury against the defendant
Don't let first impressions prejudice your judgment
These accusations could seriously prejudice his career prospects
The leak prejudiced the outcome of the negotiations
grammatical_patterns: V + O + against/in favor of + O

definitions: serve as an introduction or preliminary event to something more important
introduce or come before something as a preparatory event or action
examples: Dark clouds preluded the arrival of the storm
These negotiations prelude a comprehensive peace agreement
The pianist preluded the concert with a short improvisation
Warming exercises prelude the main training session

definitions: show a movie, play, or other performance for the first time to an audience
present or perform something as its first public appearance or debut
examples: The film will premiere at the Cannes Film Festival
The network premiered three new shows this season
The orchestra premiered the composer's latest symphony last night
She premiered her one-woman show on Broadway

definitions: base an argument, theory, or action on a particular idea or assumption
state or assume something as the basis for an argument or theory
examples: The study premises its findings on extensive field research
Her argument was premised on false assumptions
The theory premises that all humans seek happiness
He premised his decision on economic factors

definitions: make something or someone ready for use or consideration in advance
make or create something by combining various ingredients or elements
examples: She prepared thoroughly for the important job interview
The team prepared the conference room for the meeting
The chef prepared a delicious meal using fresh ingredients
Students prepared their final presentations over the weekend

definitions: authorize and recommend the use of medicine or treatment for someone as a medical professional
state officially what should be done in particular circumstances or establish as a rule
examples: The doctor prescribed antibiotics for the throat infection
Physicians can only prescribe certain controlled substances
The law prescribes severe penalties for tax evasion
Company policy prescribes the procedure for handling complaints

definitions: give something to someone as a gift or award in a formal or ceremonial way
show or display something for others to see or consider
formally introduce someone to another person or to an audience
exist or occur in a particular place or situation
examples: She presented him with a gold watch for his retirement
The mayor presented awards to outstanding community volunteers
The lawyer presented new evidence to the court
Students will present their research findings next week
May I present our distinguished guest speaker tonight
She was presented to the Queen at the ceremony
This situation presents unique challenges for our team
Several options present themselves for consideration

definitions: maintain something in its original or existing state without change or deterioration
keep something safe from harm, damage, or destruction
treat food to prevent it from decaying by using methods like canning or freezing
examples: The museum works to preserve ancient artifacts for future generations
We must preserve these traditions for our children
Environmental laws help preserve endangered species from extinction
The foundation preserves historic buildings throughout the city
She preserves fruit by making jam every summer
Salt was used to preserve meat before refrigeration

definitions: be in the position of authority in a meeting, ceremony, or formal gathering
be in charge of or have authority over a particular area or situation
examples: The chief justice will preside over the impeachment trial
She presided at the annual shareholders meeting
He presides over a vast business empire
The queen presided over an era of great change

definitions: attempt to persuade or coerce someone into doing something through force or influence
use threats or other forms of psychological force to make someone do something
examples: They pressured him to accept the unfavorable contract terms
Parents shouldn't pressure children to achieve unrealistic goals
The group pressured politicians into changing the legislation
She felt pressured to conform to social expectations

definitions: suppose that something is true without having proof or complete evidence
be audacious enough to do something that might be considered rude or inappropriate
examples: I presume you've already heard about the changes
The court presumes innocence until guilt is proven
How dare you presume to speak for everyone here
Don't presume to tell me how to do my job

definitions: behave as if something is true when you know it is not
engage in imaginary play or fantasy, especially as children do
claim to have a quality, knowledge, or feeling that one does not really have
examples: She pretended not to notice his obvious mistake
He pretended to be asleep when his parents checked
The children pretended they were pirates on an adventure
Let's pretend this box is a spaceship
He pretends to know everything about classical music
Don't pretend you care about my problems now

definitions: prove more powerful or superior in a conflict, competition, or difficult situation
exist or be widespread in a particular area or at a particular time
persuade someone to do something they initially resisted
examples: Justice will prevail despite the temporary setbacks
The home team prevailed in a closely contested match
These customs still prevail in many rural areas
Cooler temperatures prevail throughout the northern regions
She finally prevailed upon him to see a doctor
They prevailed on the committee to reconsider

definitions: stop something from happening or arising through advance planning or action
make it impossible for someone to do something or for something to occur
examples: Regular exercise helps prevent heart disease and diabetes
Security measures prevented any incidents during the event
Bad weather prevented us from leaving on schedule
The injury prevented him from playing in the finals

definitions: see or inspect something before it is generally available or officially shown
show or display something to a selected audience before the main presentation
examples: Critics were invited to preview the exhibition yesterday
You can preview the document before printing it
The studio will preview the film for industry professionals
They previewed their new collection at fashion week

definitions: hunt and kill another animal for food as a predator
exploit or take advantage of someone's weakness or vulnerability
examples: Eagles prey on small mammals and fish
Large cats prey on herbivores in the savanna
Scammers prey on elderly people living alone
These companies prey on desperate job seekers

definitions: determine and set the cost or value of something for sale or exchange
discover the unpleasant consequences or cost of something through experience
examples: The company priced their new product competitively
These items are priced too high for most customers
He priced his arrogance when everyone turned against him
You'll price your laziness when exam time comes

definitions: make a small hole in something with a sharp point or pierce the skin
cause a sharp stinging sensation physically or emotionally
examples: She accidentally pricked her finger on the rose thorn
Use a fork to prick holes in the pastry
His conscience pricked him about the lie he told
Tears pricked her eyes during the emotional scene

definitions: feel deep pleasure or satisfaction about an achievement, quality, or possession
value oneself or something highly, often taking special care of it
examples: She prides herself on always being punctual
The restaurant prides itself on using local ingredients
He prides his vintage car collection above everything
They pride their reputation for excellent service

definitions: make oneself look neat and formal in an excessively proper or precise way
behave in a stiffly formal and respectable way showing disapproval of anything improper
examples: She primmed her hair before entering the formal reception
He primmed his appearance in the mirror
She primmed her lips disapprovingly at the suggestion
The teacher primmed at the students' casual behavior

definitions: prepare something for use or action, especially by applying a preparatory coating
provide someone with information or instructions beforehand to prepare them
examples: You need to prime the walls before painting them
The mechanic primed the pump before starting it
The lawyer primed the witness before the testimony
They primed the students about what to expect

definitions: produce text or images on paper or other material using a mechanical or digital process
write words or letters clearly without joining them together
publish or include something in a newspaper, magazine, or book
examples: The printer can print fifty pages per minute
Please print three copies of this document
Children first learn to print before writing in cursive
Please print your name clearly on the form
The newspaper printed his letter to the editor
They won't print such controversial opinions

definitions: arrange or deal with things in order of importance, dealing with most important first
treat something as being more important than other things
examples: You need to prioritise your tasks for maximum efficiency
The committee prioritised applications based on urgency
The government must prioritise education and healthcare spending
She prioritises family time over career advancement

definitions: arrange or deal with things in order of importance, dealing with most important first
treat something as being more important than other things
examples: Managers must prioritize projects based on business value
Students should prioritize studying for final exams
The hospital prioritizes emergency cases over routine checkups
We prioritize customer satisfaction above profit margins

definitions: transfer a business, industry, or service from public to private ownership and control
convert something from state or public ownership to private enterprise
examples: The government plans to privatize the national railway system
Many countries privatized their telecommunications in the 1990s
They want to privatize public utilities like water and electricity
The proposal would privatize certain government services

definitions: grant a special right, advantage, or immunity to a particular person or group
exempt someone from a duty, liability, or requirement as a special favor
examples: The constitution privileges certain forms of speech
The law privileges communications between lawyers and clients
Elite members are privileged from standard security checks
Diplomatic status privileged him from local prosecution

definitions: value something or someone very highly and treat as particularly important
extract or obtain something with difficulty or effort, especially using leverage
examples: Collectors prize these rare first edition books
She prizes honesty above all other qualities
He carefully prized open the old wooden crate
Workers prized the boulder loose from the ground

definitions: officially prove the validity of a will through legal process
establish the legal validity of a document or claim through official procedures
examples: The court will probate the will next month
It took years to probate her complicated estate
The judge probated the contested document yesterday
They need to probate the inheritance claim

definitions: investigate or examine something thoroughly, especially to uncover information
physically explore or examine something with an instrument or tool
examples: Journalists probed into the politician's financial dealings
The committee will probe the causes of the accident
The dentist carefully probed the cavity with instruments
Scientists probe the ocean depths with specialized equipment

definitions: move forward or continue with a course of action, especially after a pause
begin or continue a course of action in a determined or official way
examples: After the interruption, the speaker proceeded with her presentation
Traffic can now proceed normally through the intersection
The court will proceed with the trial despite objections
Please proceed to the nearest emergency exit

definitions: announce something publicly or officially, especially something of importance
declare something officially or formally, often with authority
examples: The president proclaimed a national day of mourning
She proudly proclaimed her innocence to everyone
The judge proclaimed the defendant guilty of all charges
They proclaimed independence from colonial rule

definitions: supervise students during an examination to ensure proper conduct
monitor or oversee behavior or activities to ensure compliance with rules
examples: She will proctor the final exam this afternoon
Graduate students often proctor undergraduate examinations
The teacher proctored the online test remotely
Security staff proctor the entrance examination process

definitions: obtain something, especially with care, effort, or difficulty
obtain something for someone else, often through special arrangements
examples: The museum procured several rare artifacts for the exhibition
It's difficult to procure these parts during shortages
The agent procured tickets for the sold-out concert
She procured a specialist doctor for her client

definitions: poke someone or something with a finger or pointed object
stimulate or persuade someone to do something through persistent encouragement
examples: The child prodded the sleeping cat with a stick
She prodded him in the ribs to get his attention
His parents constantly prodded him to find a job
The coach prodded the team to train harder

definitions: make or manufacture something from components or raw materials
cause something to happen or come into existence as a result
show or provide something for inspection, consideration, or use
examples: The factory produces thousands of cars every month
Local farms produce organic vegetables for the market
These conditions produce ideal growing environments for plants
The new policy produced unexpected positive results
The lawyer produced evidence that proved innocence
Can you produce your identification please?

definitions: treat something sacred with irreverence or disrespect through words or actions
violate the sanctity of something holy or highly valued through inappropriate behavior
examples: Vandals profaned the ancient temple with graffiti
He profaned the ceremony with inappropriate jokes
They accused him of profaning religious symbols
Don't profane her memory with such lies

definitions: claim openly that one has a quality, feeling, or belief, often insincerely
declare one's faith in or allegiance to a religion or set of beliefs
teach a subject as a professor at a university
examples: He professes complete ignorance of the incident
She professed her love for him publicly
They profess Christianity but rarely attend church
He professed his faith before the congregation
She professes literature at the state university
He professed law for thirty years

definitions: describe or analyze the distinctive characteristics of a person or thing
draw, write, or present an outline or side view of something
examples: The magazine profiled several successful entrepreneurs this month
Police profiled the suspect based on witness accounts
The artist profiled her subject against the sunset
The documentary profiles the mountain from various angles
